content: A functional group is a specific grouping of atoms within molecules that is responsible for the characteristic chemical reactions of those molecules. Common functional groups include hydroxyl (–OH), carbonyl (C=O), and carboxyl (–COOH).
Alkenes are hydrocarbons that contain at least one carbon-carbon double bond (C=C). They are unsaturated and can undergo addition reactions to form alkanes.
The reaction between an alcohol and a carboxylic acid in the presence of an acid catalyst produces an ester and water. This process is known as esterification.
Hydrogenation is a chemical reaction that involves the addition of hydrogen (H2) to a compound, typically an alkene, resulting in the saturation of the molecule and forming an alkane.
The International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) provides a systematic method for naming organic chemical compounds based on their structure. For example, C5H12 is named pentane.

Electrophilic aromatic substitution is a reaction where an electrophile replaces a hydrogen atom in an aromatic compound, such as benzene. Bromination of benzene in the presence of a catalyst results in bromobenzene.
Aldehydes are organic compounds containing a carbonyl group (C=O) at the end of a carbon chain. They can be oxidized to form carboxylic acids.
Amines are derivatives of ammonia (NH3) where one or more hydrogen atoms are replaced by alkyl or aryl groups. Primary amines have one carbon atom attached to the nitrogen atom.
Isomerism is the phenomenon where two or more compounds have the same molecular formula but different structural arrangements. This includes structural isomers and stereoisomers.
A catalyst is a substance that speeds up a chemical reaction without being consumed in the process. It lowers the activation energy required for the reaction to occur.
